DOC.HEAD: Communist Leadership Meets on Lithuanian Party's Breakaway Move
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Communist Party leadership met today to deal with the Lithuanian party's unprecedented declaration of independence from the Kremlin. Lithuanian Communists voted Wednesday at a special congress in Vilnius to form their own party, rejecting appeals for unity from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other top Soviet officials. State-run Radio Moscow reported that the national party's policy-making Central Committee convened in Moscow ``to consider the situation in the Lithuanian party branch.'' The Lithuanians' break is serious because it is without precedent in the history of the party founded by Vladimir I. Lenin, who demanded and forged a unitary party across the entire territory of the Soviet Union. Lithuanian reformers predict local party organizations in many of the other 14 constituent Soviet republics may follow suit. Algirdas Brazauskas, the Lithuanian party leader, said the break, which included drafting a separate party program, was necessary for Lithuanian Communists to compete successfully in local elections Feb. 24. However, Lithuanian Communists who opposed the break formed their own leadership, and pledged continuing loyalty to Moscow. The national party leadership invited both Brazauskas and the leaders of the anti-separatist faction to Moscow to attend today's meeting, Radio Moscow said.
